raw_text:
Eastwood's Baby scoops top Oscars
 
 Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby beat Martin Scorsese's The Aviator to the top awards at the Oscars on Sunday.
 
 The boxing drama was named best picture and Eastwood pipped Scorsese to best director, while its stars Hilary Swank and Morgan Freeman won acting awards. The Aviator took five prizes including best supporting actress for Cate Blanchett. The biopic of Howard Hughes led the nominations with 11. Jamie Foxx picked up best actor for playing soul star Ray Charles in Ray. Many expected this to be Scorsese's year - but he was unsuccessful in the best director category for the fifth time in his career.
 
 He has never won despite being nominated for such films as Raging Bull and Goodfellas. Instead, Eastwood took his second Oscar for best director after winning for Unforgiven in 1993. "It was a wonderful adventure," Eastwood said. "To make a picture in 37 days, it takes a well oiled machine. I am lucky to be here and lucky to be still working. I've got a lot of stuff to do yet." Hilary Swank picked up her second best actress Oscar for playing a female boxer in Million Dollar Baby, beating stars including Annette Bening, Kate Winslet and Imelda Staunton. "I don't know what I did in this life to deserve this," she told the audience. "I'm just a girl from a trailer park who had a dream." Morgan Freeman beat actors including Clive Owen, Jamie Foxx and Alan Alda to the prize for best supporting actor. He thanked Eastwood and described the film as "a labour of love". This was the fourth nomination of his career but his first win. Backstage, he said: "A lot of people say you're due - maybe you are, maybe you aren't - it's an accolade." Million Dollar Baby's success was the night's biggest surprise after The Aviator seemed to have the advantage until the end of the ceremony.
 
 Cate Blanchett, who won for playing late screen legend Katharine Hepburn in The Aviator, said her award was "an indescribable surprise and honour". Of Hepburn, she said: "The longevity of her career is inspiring to everyone." Blanchett also paid tribute to the film's director Martin Scorsese, telling him: "I hope my son will marry your daughter." The Aviator's other awards came for cinematography, film editing, art direction and costume design. And Jamie Foxx, who had two nominations this year, paid tribute to the "beautiful legacy" of soul legend Ray Charles, who died last year, and thanked director Taylor Hackford. "You took a chance, man," he said. "That love for Ray Charles was deep down in the earth somewhere and you opened it up. "Everybody's drowning in this love. Thank you for taking a chance and thank you for waiting 15 years to get me to do it."
 
 He broke down in tears when speaking about being whipped by his grandmother, whom he described as his first acting teacher, when he was young. In other awards, cartoon hit The Incredibles won best animated feature and best sound editing. Bittersweet comedy Sideways won best adapted screenplay while the original screenplay prize went to Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Born into Brothels, about the children of prostitutes in Calcutta, was named best documentary, The Sea Inside was named best foreign language film and Finding Neverland got the accolade for best musical score. Spider-Man 2 triumphed in the visual effects category, Ray won best sound mixing and Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events picked up best make-up. Former British TV presenter Andrea Arnold, who hosted children's shows Motormouth and Number 73 in the 1980s, won best short film for Wasp. Comedian Chris Rock, who hosted the ceremony for the first time, received a standing ovation before getting the show under way.
llama3.2:1b:
Clint Eastwood won the Oscars with Million Dollar Baby, beating Martin Scorsese's The Aviator in several categories.

Eastwood won best picture and director for the film, while Hilary Swank and Morgan Freeman won acting awards. Scorsese lost his second Oscar in the directing category despite winning five other prizes including cinematography and art direction.

Many actors had previously been nominated for films by Eastwood, but he won for the first time. He thanked his team and director Eastwood. 

Swank won her second Oscar for best actress, beating Annette Bening and Kate Winslet in a close race. Freeman won his first Oscar as well.
llama3.2:3b: Million Dollar Baby won top Oscars, beating Martin Scorsese's The Aviator. Clint Eastwood took his second Oscar for best director and Hilary Swank picked up her second best actress Oscar. Morgan Freeman won best supporting actor, while Jamie Foxx won best actor. The Aviator took five prizes including best supporting actress for Cate Blanchett.
gemma2:2b: At the Oscars, Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby" won best picture and director awards. Hilary Swank won best actress and Morgan Freeman won best supporting actor. The Aviator won five awards including Cate Blanchett's award for best supporting actress. Jamie Foxx won for his portrayal of Ray Charles in "Ray."

qwen2.5:3b: Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby beat Martin Scorsese's The Aviator to win top awards at the Oscars, taking Best Picture and Director honors. Hilary Swank won Best Actress for her role as a boxer. Morgan Freeman claimed Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Million Dollar Baby. Cate Blanchett was named Best Supporting Actress for her portrayal of Katharine Hepburn in The Aviator. Jamie Foxx took home Best Actor for Ray, the latter's biopic. Other notable winners included The Incredibles for Best Animated Feature and Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind for Best Original Screenplay.
opencoder:1.5b:
Eastwood's Baby, with its top Oscars, was an exciting and successful film. It was named best picture by Clint Eastwood and pipped Scorsese to best director. The Aviator won five awards including the most supporting actor for Cate Blanchett. It was a time of success for Howard Hughes as well with 11 nominations. Jamie Foxx won best acting award after Unforgiven in 1993, a thrilling feat but it wasn't his first Oscar. In terms of movies, Raging Bull and Goodfellas were the two most anticipated.

Early onstage, Eastwood hailed the film's director Martin Scorsese as "a wonderful adventure" and described it as "an indescribable surprise and honour". For Unforgiven, he said: "I hope my son will marry your daughter." It was also noted that Cate Blanchett won an accolade for her work as a female boxer in the film.

The film was followed by The Aviator, which had a successful cast of actors like Clive Owen, Jamie Foxx and Alan Alda. It received praise for its performances and character development from director Martin Scorsese, who also praised the film's dialogue and cast. The winning combination was the end of the movie.

In terms of awards, the main ones were best animated feature and best sound editing, followed by the original screenplay prize going to Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Born into Brothels, it received an indescribable award for best documentary film. The sea inside it was also named best foreign language film.

Along with that, it won accolades for best musical score and both its animations and sound editing performances won the visual effects category. Number 73 got the accolade for best short film for Wasp. The movie also received an exceptional standing ovation from former British TV presenter Andrea Arnold who hosted children's shows Motormouth and Number 73 in the 1980s.

Overall, Eastwood's Baby represented a successful career and made a lasting impression with its performances.

tinyllama:1.1b: Eastwood's Baby scooped top Oscar awards at the 82nd Academy Awards ceremony, winning best picture, director, actor (Clint Eastwood), actress (Hilary Swank), supporting actress (Morgan Freeman), supporting actor (Alan Alda), and visual effects. The film also won four other awards for cinematography, editing, art direction, and costume design. Cathe Blanchett won the best actress award for her role as Katharina Hepburn in The Aviator, while Jamie Foxx received the Best Actor Award for playing Ray Charles in Ray, his second nomination. Cathe Blanchett paid tribute to Ray Charles during the ceremony, saying she was inspired by his legacy and thanked director Taylor Haackford. Other winners included Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind for best adapted screenplay, The Sea Inside for best foreign language film, Spider-Man 2 for visual effects, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events for make-up, and Sideways for best animated feature.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Eastwood's Baby outpaced Martin Scorsese's The Aviator to secure top prizes at the Oscars on Sunday. In the lead acting categories, Clint Eastwood pipped Scorsese for best actor and Hilary Swank secured the gold for best actress. Million Dollar Baby won best picture, while best director went to Eastwood and best supporting actress to Swank. The Aviator took five Oscars but was overlooked by Martin Scorsese in the best director category. However, Eastwood's 37-day filming experience allowed him to make the second Oscar for his best director win, while Cate Blanchett won for her portrayal of Katharine Hepburn in The Aviator. Heppurn is a late screen legend with an inspiring career, which inspired actress Jamie Foxx to marry his daughter. Both Eastwood and Scorsese received nominations for best film, but Eastwood's Baby secured the top prize.
phi:2.7b: Clint Eastwood's movie "Million Dollar Baby" claimed top honors at the Oscars, beating Martin Scorsese's "The Aviator". The box office drama won best picture and its director and stars were also recognized with awards. This was a surprise for many as Scorsese is one of Hollywood's most successful directors but he couldn't take home the best director award this year. Eastwood has been nominated several times before but has only won for his film "Unforgiven" in 2003. Hilary Swank, who played a boxer in "Million Dollar Baby", took home best actress while Morgan Freeman, who portrayed soul singer Ray Charles in the biopic "Ray", won best supporting actor. The Aviator's success was largely due to its director Martin Scorsese but it had 11 nominations. Backstage, Scorsese thanked Eastwood and described making a film in 37 days as a "well oiled machine". Meanwhile, Cate Blanchett, who won for her role as Katharine Hepburn in "The Aviator", spoke about the longevity of Hepburn's career and praised Martin Scorsese. Other awards were given to "The Incredibles" for best animated feature, "Sideways" for best adapted screenplay and "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" for best original screenplay. The documentary "Born into Brothels" won best documentary and "Spider-Man 2" was named best visual effects film. "Ray", which had the best sound mixing, received a special Tony Award this year. The ceremony ended with comedian Chris Rock receiving a standing ovation before leading the audience in singing "Happy Birthday to You".
